Flood Recovery to Resilience Programme, Tajikistan is a two year effort which aims to reduce risk and build resilience
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Affected households provided with cows and poultry. 2. Vaccination and regular examination of distributed animals conducted. 3. Seeds and fertilizer for household garden production distributed. 4. Tools and fencing for household gardens distributed. 5. Sustainable water supply system constructed. 6. Trainings for existing Water User Association (WUA) on water management provided. 7. Equipment for operation and management of the water system provided. 8. Site design for reallocation site developed 9. Houses for most affected households constructed. 10. Health center in Chubek jamoat repaired. 11. Health center for relocated population at new settlement constructed. 12. Flood and mudflow assessment conducted involving international and local expertise. 13. Hazard management plan developed for Sarichashma watershed. 14. Awareness raising and consultation activities conducted. 15. Hazard warning system established. 16. Technical support on weather forecast provided. 17. Weather data collection equipment installed. 18. Trainings on weather data collection and analysis conducted. 19. Conduction of risk and hazard assessments. 20. Development of jamoat resilience plan.

comment.narrative:
On 12-13 April 2014, due to heavy rains and hailstorm flash floods and mudslides hit several districts of Kulyab zone, south east of Khatlon Province. Namely Hamadoni, Kulyab, Muminobod, Shuroobod and Vose districts were affected. Severely affected areas include Sarichashma Jamoat of Shuroobod district, Tugarak Jamoat of Vose district and Balkhobi Jamoat of Muminobod district. Fifteen people fell victim to the disaster during the first two days. Significant damages have been observed in more than 487 households, livelihoods and local infrastructure, including health and education facilities. Severely affected communities include Sarichashma jamoat of Shuroobod district, where in addition to the 104 families affected, more than 500 head of the cattle has been killed. The affected population of more than 780 people has been relocated to tent camp. Under current component the livelihood support activities are envisaged to restore normal livelihood of those affected.
The current setback to the immediate implementation of the relocation plan is that the Bobo Nosirov site lacks a sustainable water supply. While an existing section of Bobo Nosirov (settled some decades ago) has access to piped water, assessments indicate that the supply is currently insufficient for the additional relocated families. The relocation cannot take place if the families to be moved do not have access to water, making a water supply system a prerequisite for moving families to a safer location. It is foreseen to establish a sustainable water supply for the Bobo Nosirov relocation site. This will involve extension of the existing spring source to handle increased demand through spring development, pumps, pipes, storage facilities and a reticulation system with household meters. The water system will be run through an existing water user association (WUA), with operating costs covered through fees collected based on household water use meters. The Government has already established a site plan
8. 15 houses
8. 18 houses are under the construction, which will be accomplished and handed over to the flood affected households by the end of 2016.
8. 18 houses
8. 18 houses were constructed and handed over.

comment.narrative: 1. State Agency Legal Aid Centre is established and hired at least 15 employees 2. At least two training condcuted for State Agency Legal Aid Centre lawyers 3. 3,000 free legal aid provided and at least 60% of women 4. Working Group on adoption of UN Convention on Rights of People with Disability finalized its work 5. Number of households with no documents decreased from 13% to 10% in Project areas

1. State Agency Legal Aid Centre was established under the MoJ early 2016. By the end of 2016 it had 7 central apparatus employees and 10 lawyers working in 6 LACs countrywide. 2. Two capacity development trainings were conducted for SALAC employees on different counselling issues by the Project directly and three other trainings were conducted by the Project`s partner. 3. Overall 3,109 free legal aid have been provided countrywide through NGO run and SALAC LACs out of which 74% was women. 4. Working Group on adoption of UN CRPD has finalized its work and recommended Tajikistan to join UN CRPD. Within the frame of UPR procedure Tajikistan committed to join the UNCRPD. 5. This target and accordingly all activities have been removed from the Project document as a result of Project Document revision approved by donors. Specialized UNDP Project on CR will be working on those issues.

1. SALAC expands and its employees reached to at least 20 persons. 2. SALAC LACs provide at least 1,000 LA countrywide, where 60% (600) are women. 3. Tajikistan signs UN CRPD 4. PWD specific legal Aid Centre established and provides at least 200 consultations out of which 60% (120) women. 5. Tajikistan adopts NPA on UPR implementation. 6. Draft commentary of criminal execution code is elaborated.

1. in 2017 SALAC has expanded and as of end of 2017 it has 20 lawyers and 8 employees at central office and 4 at Call-Center for Secondary Free legal Aid. 2. In 2017 SALAC has provided 4886 legal aid out of which 2789 women 3. Delayed. Expected to be signed early 2018. 4. PWD specific Legal Aid Centre was established and provided legal aid to 478 people with disabilities out of which 215 women. 5. Tajikistan has adopted NPA on UPR recommendations implementation on June 7, 2017. 6. Draft commentary to criminal execution code was elaborated.

There is no comprehensive disability strategy of Tajikistan is not fully addressing the rights of persons with disabilities that are in line with the the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and other international instruments.

description.narrative: Border Management in Northern Afghanistan II. To support Cross-border Security and Cooperation, by improving Integrated Border Management in northern Afghanistan.
capital of a political entity
Defence - policy, planning and administration

Output 1: - Number of ABP officers and staff trained. - Number of Border Police Units benefiting from the presence and capacity building activities of Training and Mentoring Team (s). - Number of ABP units benefiting from BOMNAF developed training materials. - Number of Border management infrastructure built, furnished and equipped. - BOMNAF provided facilities and equipment are well maintained and supported - Number of officers stationed at BOMNAF constructed facilities received specialized equipment.
Output 2: - Development of an implementation plan on interagency and cross-border cooperation - Number of field events facilitated and supported. - Number of joint meetings and high level seminars supported between border officials from Afghanistan with their counterpart from Central Asia.
Output 3: - Creation and functionality of the Regional Technical Working Group - Number of joint activities between borderland communities and ABP - Number of joint cross-border workshops, symposia at Border Crossing Points - Number of joint patrolling activities - Adopted conference declaration - Number of regional development and cross-border initiatives supported.

comment.narrative: - Weak capacity and efficiency of ABP on Border Management on Afghanistan’s Northern border. - Weak inter-agency and cross-border communication, cooperation, and coordination between Afghanistan and Central Asia - Weak collaboration between border management agencies with the borderland residents.

1. Up to 300 beneficiaries are trained in Integrated Border Management, and associated subjects, including Transparency, Integrity and Accountability (TIA) 2. At least two Border Police Units (40‐200 personnel at each location), benefited from the presence and capacity building activities of Training and Mentoring Team(s) 3. Training Centre in Mazar-e-Sharif constructed; 4. Construction of the Battalion HQ in Chashmai Tut completed; 5. Renovation of Border Crossing Point- Sheghnan completed (as part of maintenance plan provided to EU facilities); 6. Construction of two Border Crossing Points and one Regional HQ building started and in process. 7. Procurement of specialized equipment for Afghan Border Police is in process. 8. A field event for involving border and customs officials is organized and facilitated. 9. A Regional Technical Working Group (TWG) for border practitioners created. 10. Up to 50 beneficiaries trained in anti‐corruption and integrity, including instruction on professional ethics. 11. Up to 3 community-policing meetings with community and border forces are organized. 12. Up to 350 posters and pamphlets about border crossing, narcotic and trafficking are developed and distributed. 13. Up to 3 community training on DRM are conducted.

description.narrative: Project title: Promoting Cross-border Cooperation through effective management of Tajikistan’s border with Afghanistan
third-order administrative division
Defence - policy, planning and administration

- Implementation status of the National Strategy on Border Management and National Strategy on Drug Abuse; - Number of people crossing the border per week, including on the market days (gender segregated)

comment.narrative: - Implementation of National Strategy on Border Management and National Strategy on Drug Abuse is slow; - 1,050 people cross the Tajik-Afghan border on market days and 25 people on non-market days;

1. • UNDP, OSCE and IOM signed a MoU to jointly implement this activity. JICA-BMP contracted an international expert, who, together with OSCE expert, reviewed the National Border Management Strategy. • Review of National Border Management Strategy and its implementation plan for 2010-2025 and recommendations was completed on 7 Jul 2016. • Requirement now is to formally hand-over the review report and recommendations to the national government. Response awaited from MFA. 2. During 25 September to 01 October 2016, a delegation consisting of six members of the two Interagency National Border Management and Counter-Narcotics Strategy Secretariats undertook a study visit to the UK. The specific objective of the tour was to assist beneficiaries to gain an improved understanding of good practices in Counter Narcotics (CN), Border Management (BM) and customs procedures from other countries’ practitioners and border agencies. It was a very useful and instructive Study tour for members of the Secretariats. 3. Design works completed by end July 2016; 4 Border Detachment Commander’s office in Khorogh renovation is completed; 5. Procurement of furniture and equipment for border guards at BCPs is announced and ongoing. Furniture and equipment will be procured in accordance with requests received from beneficiaries. 6. • 26-30 September 2016. Border Management Awareness Course for Tajikistan Border Force (TBF), Tajikistan Customs Service (TCS), and the Drug Control Agency (DCA). • Jul-Dec 2016: Total 60 officers trained. • Year 2016: Total 127 beneficiary officers trained. 7. Construction works started and ongoing at the site.

1. At the request of the beneficiary, the review of the action and costing plan was conducted by the project and handed over to the National Counter Narcotics Strategy Secretariat on July 31, 2017. 2. During 16 to 21 October 2017, a delegation consisting of six members of the two Interagency National Border Management and Counter-Narcotics Strategy Secretariats undertook a study visit to the Georgia. The specific objective of the tour was to assist beneficiaries to gain an improved understanding of good practices in Counter Narcotics (CN), Border Management (BM) and customs procedures from other countries’ practitioners and border agencies. It was a very useful and instructive Study tour for members of the Secretariats. 3. Because of harsh climate and road conditions of the Langar Border Crossing Point site, as well as security concerns, completion of this BCP construction is delayed until early 2018. 4. Furniture and equipment was delivered to 5 BCPs (Tem, Ruzvai, Shohon, Khumrogi and Ishkashim). Equipment and furniture will be provided to BCP Langar after the completion of construction. 5. Four training courses were conducted during the year as per following details: • 12-16 June: BMP Training for Customs & TBF Officers. • 21-25 June: Disaster Risk Management Training. • 3-13 July: BMP and BOMNAF joint Border Management Awareness training. • Joint DRM training was held with the participation of the Tajik and Afghan border guards with a goal of improving border cooperation. 6. Rusvai and Ishkashim cross border markets were upgraded and all works are completed

description.narrative: The project aims to build the capacities of the Committee of Emergency Situations and Civil Defense in preparedness to disaster response operations
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.1.1 # of round tables conducted. 1.1.2 Roadmap developed. 1.2.1 # of legal documents amended 1.2.2 # of protocols and procedures developed. 2.2.1 Capacity needs assessment conducted. 2.2.2 Recommendations on needs improvement developed. 2.3.1 # of heavy machinery procured. 2.3.2 Separate entity under CoES for O&M of heavy machinery established.

comment.narrative: Situation analysis showed that government lacks of unified emergency preparedness and response system in the country and the preparedness capacity both at central and regional (local) levels are limited. In order to deal with the challenges and capacity gaps mentioned above, the CoES identified the Russian Unified State Emergency Preparedness and Response System as an optimal model for replication. The Decree # 833 as of 31 December 2014, on establishment of a Unified Emergency Preparedness and Response System has been issued, but many relevant secondary legislation, protocols and procedures are not on line with requirements on effective functioning of the unified system. Professional intervention teams will be trained and prepared to fulfil specific roles in carrying out rescue operations and take measures such as (temporary) evacuations when needed. These measures aim at minimizing the loss of life and physical damage as well as the consequences during the onset of a disaster. It is suggested that, after a thorough assessment, the heavy rescue equipment required for debris clearance and rescue works in avalanches and mudflows will be procured. At the same time, as CoES is constrained to budget necessary funds to maintain this equipment as a stand-by capacity, it is suggested to develop a business model for a commercial entity to be developed within COES structure, to allow the equipment to be used on a for-hire basis when the equipment is not needed for emergency operations. By developing an appropriate business and operations plan which enables the proper operation and maintenance of the equipment base so that the equipment will be made immediately available in case of disasters.

1.1.1 At least 2 round tables conducted. 1.1.2 A roadmap developed and establishment of the unified system agreed. 1.2.1 All relevant legal documents amended. 1.2.2 At least 2 protocols and procedures are developed. 2.2.1 Tsentrospas capacity gaps revealed. 2.2.2 Capacity development plan elaborated. 2.3.1 At least 10 heavy rescue machinery procured. 2.3.2 Business plan for establishment of commercial structure for O&M of machinery developed.

1.1.1 Negotiation with relevant stakeholders and counterparts were initiation and hiring the required international and national staff was started. 1.1.2 postponed to 2018. 1.2.1 postponed to 2018. 1.2.2 0. 2.2.1 Tsentrospas capacity gaps revealed. 2.2.2 Capacity development plan elaborated. 2.3.1 International tender bidding process for procurement and delivery of the heavy machinery for CoES conducted. 2.3.2 postponed to 2018.

comment.narrative: - 0 models of secondary legal aid piloted. - 20% - 15 national and 0 regional NGOs take part in the National Policy Dialogue, including no women’s NGOs or OPWDs - 2 national policy/legal justice reforms informed by the State legal aid structures - no follow up mechanism.
The project started in December 2016, hence no programmatic targets and results were set for 2016.
The project started in December 2016, hence no programmatic targets and results were set for 2016.

1. 10 secondary LA cases have been taken in each piloted district 2. 20 Bailiffs and 20 Judges covered with capacity development trainings 3.
